This is an Atom formatted XML site feed. It is intended to be viewed in a Newsreader. Alternatively you can view the HTML archives at https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A0=ARCH-GLASS.
LISTSERV Web Interface 2.4.1 2015-03-12T20:34:14Z PRICE A.J. 2015-03-12T20:24:03+00:00 2015-03-12T20:24:03+00:00 Re: Association for the History of Glass on Twitter https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;c18ebd60.1503 Chloe - good work, I am glad that you have done that. I am currently working through various references and review statements but will forward my Fazzan notes to you tomorrow am - best wishes, Jenny ________________________________________ From: Archaeological Glass Research Forum [ARCH-GLASS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] on behalf of Chloe Duckworth [cd227@LE.AC.UK] Sent: 12 March 2015 19:36 To: ARCH-GLASS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK Subject: Association for the History of Glass on Twitter The Association for the History of Glass now has a Twitter account, which you can find here: https://twitter.com/Ass_Hist_Glass Chloe Chloe Duckworth 2015-03-12T19:36:42+00:00 2015-03-12T19:36:42+00:00 Association for the History of Glass on Twitter https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;c24065fb.1503 The Association for the History of Glass now has a Twitter account, which you can find here: https://twitter.com/Ass_Hist_Glass<br>Chloe Andrea Ceglia 2015-01-30T10:56:46+01:00 2015-01-30T10:56:46+01:00 Re: data from literature https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;92543659.1501 Thank you Chloe!<br>I have the pdf version of Brill's book. Still when you import the data in<br>excel there is still quite some manual work to do. That's why I was<br>wondering if someone had already done it.<br>Well, when I will do it, I will be happy to share my data. I have also .txt<br>files for some other datasets ready to be shared if you need<br>(Foster&Jackson2009,Drauschke2010,Gallo2012,Conte2014,Rosenow2014...). [...] Duckworth, Chloe N. (Dr.) 2015-01-30T09:18:25+00:00 2015-01-30T09:18:25+00:00 Re: data from literature https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;233cad2.1501 The first two Brill books are readily available as PDFs (http://www.cmog.org/library/chemical-analyses-early-glasses-robert-h-brill), and I think the quickest method with these is to copy the data to a text file and then import it into Excel with space delimiting. As for other scans, you should look into optical character recognition (OCR) software to convert images to text files. For example: http://www.onlineocr.net/ [...] Katharina Schmidt 2015-01-30T09:44:44+01:00 2015-01-30T09:44:44+01:00 AW: data from literature https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;513f7754.1501 Dear Andrea,<br>Sound very interesting. As I am working in earlier periods I can only offer Brill Vol.1 and 2 as Pdf which you probably have yourself? Do you want to give me your USB stick as the data is too big to send it!<br><br>As I am new in the field of archaeological materials I would be very happy if you could show me quickly how you exactly you put the old data together. That would help me very much! [...] Andrea Ceglia 2015-01-30T08:18:29+00:00 2015-01-30T08:18:29+00:00 data from literature https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;861698da.1501 Hi,<br><br>I would like to plot published data of Roman, Late Roman, Islamic and Sassanian glasses to compare my data.<br><br>I am normally copying data from the literature. When have a pdf file is relatively easy.<br>Nevertheless, now I am starting with Brill's Chemical analysis of early glass and the French literature (Foy, Nenna, Picon, Thirion-Merle), but I only have scanned copies of those. [...] Chloe Duckworth 2015-01-20T15:07:11+00:00 2015-01-20T15:07:11+00:00 Recycling Things and Ideas https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;16224374.1501 Please also see below the following call for papers, for next year's EAAs in Glasgow<br><br>CALL FOR PAPERS! Recycling things and ideas: linking scientific, archaeological and conceptual approaches to the reuse of materials in the past<br><br>Dr. Peter Bray, RLAHA, University of Oxford (peter.bray@rlaha.ox.ac.uk); Dr. Aur\ufffd\ufffdlie Cu\ufffd\ufffdnod, University of Leicester; Dr. Chlo\ufffd\ufffd Duckworth, University of Leicester; Patrick Degryse, KU Leuven; Marianne M\ufffd\ufffddlinger, University of Vienna [...] Chloe Duckworth 2015-01-20T09:50:56+00:00 2015-01-20T09:50:56+00:00 Glass Making in the Greco-Roman World https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;ae958574.1501 Please see message below about a much-anticipated, open access book:<br><br>Dear friends, colleagues,<br><br>A book that may be of interest to you: 'Glass Making in the Greco-Roman World', open access, online on OAPEN \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd http://www.oapen.org/search?identifier=513796 (paper copies are also available).<br><br>Please do not send around the book as pdf, but feel absolutely free to spread the link: downloads are counted, and are important as a case for open access publication of books and data. [...] Paynter, Sarah 2014-12-11T15:00:23+00:00 2014-12-11T15:00:23+00:00 Re: ARCH-GLASS Digest - 9 Dec 2014 to 10 Dec 2014 (#2014-3) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;2585c024.1412 Yes with the material from English sites there are differences in the extent of chemical attack on crucibles depending on crucible fabric and glass composition, with both changing for different periods. The rate of dissolution also appears to differ for the different components of the crucible - in some the matrix has largely gone in the interaction layer whereas quartz grains remain only partially dissolved, whereas in others (alumina-rich crucibles from later periods) there is less overall interaction of crucible with glass. There also appear to be differences in the rate of diffusion of different elements from the interaction layer [...] Freestone, Ian 2014-12-11T09:12:15+00:00 2014-12-11T09:12:15+00:00 Re: ARCH-GLASS Digest - 9 Dec 2014 to 10 Dec 2014 (#2014-3) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;ad794a10.1412 Dear All<br>I am not so convinced about the possibilities of alumina contamination from a crucible. One can do the calculations quite easily to work out that a cylindrical crucible 10 cm internal diameter filled with 20 cm glass will contaminate the glass by about 0.5% Al2O3 for every 1 mm crucible lining lost, assuming an earthenware crucible with about 20% Al2O3. This number could go up if the crucible fabric was very dense or if the crucible was made of kaolinite. However, as the crucible gets larger, the reduced surface area to volume ratio means that the amount of [...] Julian Henderson 2014-12-10T18:01:16+00:00 2014-12-10T18:01:16+00:00 PS: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;a0d57607.1412 Hi Chloe,<br>More parallels amongst the al-Raqqa glasses published in Archaeometry 2004. Figure 8 from the publication is attached which gives you an idea.<br>Best,<br>Julian Paynter, Sarah 2014-12-10T11:05:47+00:00 2014-12-10T11:05:47+00:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;a84210ec.1412 Dear Chloe,<br>On the subject of contamination during glassworking you could look at some of the reports from the EH Research Department Report Series, which are all now digitised (searchable through the website (http://research.english-heritage.org.uk/). There are analyses of waste form glassworking sites, mainly in reports by David Dungworth, with a few by others. There are also masses of data on medieval and post-medieval glass but different types to yours unfortunately. There is also a paper in Glass Studies (Paynter 2008 Experiments in the Reconstruction of Roman Wood-Fired Glassworking Furnaces: Waste Products and Their Formation Processes. 50: 271\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd290).<br>Sarah Duckworth, Chloe N. (Dr.) 2014-12-10T10:58:52+00:00 2014-12-10T10:58:52+00:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;e0630e74.1412 Slight mistype in my first message - we have up to 3.4% Al2O3 in glasses from both Cordoba and Malaga, though there is more variation in the unpublished Malaga set.<br><br>I think this is relatively high by comparison even with Serce Limani, so Teresa, it may be of interest to you. I am happy to share the unpublished data with you if you wish to look at it yourself - please email me if so. In any case, I'm going to work on it over the Christmas period and get these latest data into press asap. [...] Julian Henderson 2014-12-10T08:50:23+00:00 2014-12-10T08:50:23+00:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;d6f9808d.1412 Full message available at: <a href="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;d6f9808d.1412">Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses </a> Teresa Medici 2014-12-10T09:08:59+01:00 2014-12-10T09:08:59+01:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;b543e3be.1412 Dear Chloe and Arch-glass list members,<br><br>What we found in 17th c. soda ash glass excavated in Portugal and consider<br>as high alumina content is more than 3 wt% . We are using this grouping<br>criteria: high alumina (3\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd6 wt%), very high alumina (>6 wt%), as published<br>by Lima et al. 2012 in the Journal of Archaeological Science (<br>http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305440312000180). [...] Peter Robertshaw 2014-12-09T21:24:57+00:00 2014-12-09T21:24:57+00:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;b60753c.1412 Chloe (and others),<br><br>Your Al levels are, of course, ridiculously low in comparison to the Indian glass that was used to make many of the beads found in southern Africa. However, what may be of interest in the light of Colin's remarks is that, although the beads from the site of K2 in southern Africa generally have very high Al levels, those beads of the type known as "Garden Rollers" have even higher levels of Al. This type of bead is thought to have been made on site in clay crucibles, examples of which have been recovered. [...] Duckworth, Chloe N. (Dr.) 2014-12-09T21:10:07+00:00 2014-12-09T21:10:07+00:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;c048a273.1412 Thanks very much to all for the advice. Rather stupid of me to ignore the Serce Limani results here, but I'm very grateful to have been made aware of this.<br><br>One of the difficulties we have is that we simply need to run more analyses of Spanish glass. We're still not sure how much the variability in these glasses is a result of different provenances, or heterogeneous raw materials/production techniques/furnaces... We have just analysed several glasses from Malaga, and they have different compositions again (including a sample from a furnace wall with very high Al). By comparison with these at [...] Colin Brain 2014-12-09T15:02:54+00:00 2014-12-09T15:02:54+00:00 Re: High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;4b453525.1412 Hi Chloe, Sand could be the cause of the higher iron and alumina, but there are a couple of other possibilities.\ufffd\ufffd One is from the pot clay.\ufffd\ufffd I recall David Dungworth did some calculations some while ago that suggested that it would be feasible for the glass melt to dissolve sufficient pot clay to pick up that order of contamination.\ufffd\ufffd Another possibility is the technique used to purify the plant ashes (if indeed any purification was used).\ufffd\ufffd Whilst quite a bit of work has been done on the composition of ashes from different plants, there does not appear to have [...] Freestone, Ian 2014-12-09T12:53:39+00:00 2014-12-09T12:53:39+00:00 Re: ARCH-GLASS Digest - <first ever> to 8 Dec 2014 (#2014-1) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;753c42b2.1412 Hi Chloe<br><br>Serce Limani glass typically has 1.5% - 2.5% Al2O3 and 0.7% Fe2O3 (reduced values) so I don't see those results as being unusual really.<br><br>Best<br>Ian<br><br>-----Original Message-----<br>From: Archaeological Glass Research Forum [mailto:ARCH-GLASS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of ARCH-GLASS automatic digest system<br>Sent: 09 December 2014 00:03<br>To: ARCH-GLASS@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: ARCH-GLASS Digest - <first ever> to 8 Dec 2014 (#2014-1) [...] Chloe Duckworth 2014-12-08T13:24:39+00:00 2014-12-08T13:24:39+00:00 High iron and alumina plant ash glasses https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;aae1e14f.1412 Dear Arch-glass list members,<br><br>I am working on the interpretation of Islamic glasses from medieval Spain, from the 8th/9th century to the 13th century AD. We are finding that we consistently see quite high alumina (c.1.5-2.5% Al2O3) and iron oxide (0.6-1.5% FeO) for plant ash glasses, compared with almost all contemporary published examples from elsewhere in the Islamic and Mediterranean world (more detail on our analysis of glasses from Cordoba is available in our Archaeometry paper: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/arcm.12079/abstract). [...] Paynter, Sarah 2014-10-20T16:40:19+01:00 2014-10-20T16:40:19+01:00 Medieval glass phials used as reliquaries https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;a2d091b4.1410 Dear list, I have had an enquiry from a researcher that you may be able to help with. The researcher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds name is Greg Campbell and he says: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRecently I have begun looking at medieval use of shell imagery, initially with scallop-shells used as Santiago de Compostela pilgrimage badges. This led to a survey of shell-images on lead-alloy pilgrim ampullae using the Portable Antiquities Scheme examples. These lead ampullae clearly have two forms, one imitating a pilgrim-scallop, the other something else. That something else would appear to be a small glass ampulla or phial, suspended in a drawstring bag. So I [...] Colin Brain 2014-10-18T17:25:12+00:00 2014-10-18T17:25:12+00:00 Re: ARCH-GLASS Digest - <first ever> to 17 Oct 2014 (#2014-1) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;3c7d91aa.1410 Hi Ian, Thanks for the information.\ufffd\ufffd I had found some blue French dichroic glass flasks in the J. Paul Getty Museum, the Museum Grunes Gewolbe Dresden and the Toledo Museum of Art, but I had not realised there were any of these in the BM.\ufffd\ufffd these seem to have been attributed to the period 1550-1600, but I am not aware of any related pre or post production or any work on how these might have been developed\ufffd\ufffd The ones I was looking at seem to be part of a separate development at least 50 years later, although it would be [...] Chloe Duckworth 2014-10-18T13:01:39+01:00 2014-10-18T13:01:39+01:00 Welcome and notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;2b93d790.1410 Hello and welcome to the ARCH-GLASS mailing list.<br><br>Thank you for signing up, and to all those who have sent positive feedback. I'm pleased to see that I wasn't the only one who thought this list would be of use. It's also great to see that we already have a discussion thread going, on various glassy 'odds and sods'. [...] Freestone, Ian 2014-10-18T07:35:24+00:00 2014-10-18T07:35:24+00:00 Re: ARCH-GLASS Digest - <first ever> to 17 Oct 2014 (#2014-1) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;6fc9e903.1410 Hi Colin<br>There are some post med dichroic glasses from France in the BM. I looked them years ago with Aileen Dawson. They were deep turning a kind of orange yellow. I think Aileen published them somewhere.<br>On the etching issue, what acid would they have used at that time?<br>Best<br>Ian<br><br>Ian Freestone<br>Sent from my iPhone [...] Freestone, Ian 2014-10-18T07:36:52+00:00 2014-10-18T07:36:52+00:00 Re: ARCH-GLASS Digest - <first ever> to 17 Oct 2014 (#2014-1) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;da434a18.1410 Sorry, i meant they were deep BLUE turning......<br><br>Ian Freestone<br>Sent from my iPhone<br><br>> On 18 Oct 2014, at 00:19, "ARCH-GLASS automatic digest system" <LISTSERV@JISCMAIL.AC.UK> wrote:<br>><br>> There is 1 message totaling 53 lines in this issue.<br>><br>> Topics of the day:<br>><br>> 1. There is always an odd one..<br>><br>> ----------------------------------------------------------------------<br>><br>> Date: Fri, 17 Oct 2014 15:15:02 +0000<br>> From: Colin Brain <cbrain@INTERALPHA.CO.UK><br>> Subject: There is always an odd one..<br>><br>> Hi,<br>><br>> First thanks to Chloe for starting this list.<br>><br>> At the recent GlassAC14 conference I [...] Colin Brain 2014-10-17T15:15:02+00:00 2014-10-17T15:15:02+00:00 There is always an odd one.. https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=ARCH-GLASS;b2c83f18.1410 Hi, First thanks to Chloe for starting this list. At the recent GlassAC14 conference\ufffd\ufffd I did a scratch presentation to fill a gap called "There is always an odd one ..."\ufffd\ufffd The title was picked up from a number of speakers describing archaeological glass assemblages.\ufffd\ufffd The odd two glasses I highlighted were a post medieval dichroic opal glass and a 17th C bowl-wall fragment that included twisted canes in the decoration, but where the cane twist was asymmetric and half of the twist appears to have been deliberately removed by selective etching (see http://www.glassac14.sgt.org/Ab-ColinBrain3.htm).\ufffd\ufffd Does anyone have any ideas or [...]
